explanation:
- osal_objtype_t: You must know the underlying type (enum, typedef, integer width) and its range/semantics to decide if the switch controlling expression can be treated as invariant or if it can take different runtime values.
- OS_OBJECT_TYPE_OS_* (all case labels listed): The exact definitions/values of these constants are needed to understand the set of distinct values the controlling expression is compared against. If these constants were mis-defined (e.g. all equal) it could make the switch degenerate; their definitions also show whether they are compile-time constants (they normally are) but do not by themselves determine invariance of the function parameter.
- OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken, OS_ObjectIdFindNextMatch, OS_ObjectIdFindNextFree, OS_ObjectIdIteratorInit: These are the direct callers of OS_GetBaseForObjectType (per the call graph). To determine whether the switch control expression (idtype) can be invariant at runtime you must inspect these callers to see how they obtain and pass the osal_objtype_t argument (e.g. are they always passing a fixed literal/enum constant or do they pass a variable/derived value). If any caller always supplies a single constant value, that caller-context could make idtype invariant in practice; conversely if callers pass variable values then the expression is not invariant.  (Therefore the implementations/prototypes and call sites of these caller functions must be examined.)
